thread.title: Axa's US IPO comes up $1 billion short

author: Hugh Son
title: Axa's US IPO comes up $1 billion short
text: Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Axa Equitable initial public offering comes up $1 billion short The IPO raised $2.75 billion, making it the biggest U.S. initial public offering this year but it still fell short of Axa's targeted range. Morgan Stanley and JP Morgan led the offering. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Axa Equitable initial public offering comes up $1 billion short Hugh Son, Liz Moyer, CNBC Published 1:11 p.m. ET May 10, 2018 | Updated 2:32 p.m. ET May 10, 2018 A rising stock-price bar chart overlaid on a monitor displaying stock-price quotes (Photo: GETTY IMAGES) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Axa's $15.3 billion takeover of global property casualty firm XL Group was a monster deal in the insurance world, but Paris-based Axa's plan to pay for the acquisition has come up short. The French company is selling its U.S. business, Axa Equitable Holdings, in an initial public offering. But the money it raised was about $1 billion less than the goal. The IPO priced at $20 a share, below the expected $24 to $27 per share range. It opened trading at $19.75 on Thursday at the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol EQH. At $2.75 billion in proceeds, the deal is still the largest U.S. IPO of the year, according to Renaissance Capital. But it was far less than the $3.7 billion it had expected to raise at the high end of the pricing range. Insurers have been a beaten-down sector this year. Principal Financial shares are down more than 17 percent, while shares of Prudential Financial and Lincoln National are both down more than 12 percent, and shares of MetLife have fallen 7.7 percent.
